qas.question: Who expounded the earliest recorded Western philosophy of time?
When do the Vedas date back to?
Which philosophies are the Vedas oriented with?
How long is the cycle of rebirth discussed in the Vedas?
What was first recorded in the 26th century BC.
Who warned people not to increase the time o following desire?
What is the name of the earliest Egyptian texts?
How long did the Greeksd think a cyle of time was?

context: The earliest recorded <b5_0>Western philosophy of time<b5_0/> was expounded by the ancient <b6_0>Egyptian thinker <a0_0>Ptahhotep<b6_0/><a0_0/> (c. 2650–2600 BC), who said, "Do not lessen the time of following desire, for the wasting of time is an abomination to the spirit." The <b7_0><b8_0>Vedas<b8_0/><b7_0/>, the earliest texts on <a2_0>Indian philosophy and Hindu philosophy<a2_0/>, dating back to the <a1_0>late 2nd millennium BC<a1_0/>, describe <a3_0>ancient Hindu cosmology<a3_0/>, in which the universe goes through repeated cycles of creation, destruction, and rebirth, with each cycle lasting <a4_0><b9_0>4,320,000 years<b9_0/><a4_0/>. Ancient Greek philosophers, including Parmenides and Heraclitus, wrote essays on the nature of time.
